A firefight broke out - wounding at least two soldiers and two civilians - whilst two of the intercepted soldiers fled, killing a Ugandan civilian as they fled through Mingkaman town.

source: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Juba Monitor; New York Times; Radio Tamazuj; UN Panel of Experts; VOA
notes: On 9 August 2020, armed youth (described as 'Gelweng' (cattle guards), and presumed to be Rek Dinka) attacked SSPDF at Romich in Tonj East county (Warrap state), following an earlier incident in which one or two of their kinsmen were killed by soldiers. At least 148 were killed in two days of fighting, including 63 soldiers, and 94 wounded (fatalities evenly distributed across two events). SSPDF used tanks and heavy artillery. Hundreds have been displaced, and the market was looted and torched. A Sudanese trader was among the dead, and two colleagues of the trader were also wounded. The clashes are likely related to a power struggle between Internal Director of the National Security Service and the President (backed by Military Intelligence).

On 22 July 2020, Mundari and Bari militias clashed in the Mangalla area of Juba county (Central Equatoria state), in a dispute over ownership of the area. At least one member of the Bari was killed.

source: Mali Actu; AMAP; Essor; Undisclosed Source
notes: On 21 July 2020, unknown gunmen killed two gendarmes and seized their weapons in the city of Gao (Gao, Gao).

actor1: PRNC: Party of the Rally of the Central African Nation

actor2: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

assoc_actor_2: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
source: IWACU; Radio Publique Africaine; SOS Medias
notes: On 20 July 2020, Interahamwe clashed with Burundian military forces and Imbonerakure in Kabira forest near Torero and Gafumbegeti hills in Butahana zone (Mabayi, Cibitoke). 7 Burundian soldiers were killed and at least 4 were injured. 5 from the Interahamwe were captured and sent back to Rwanda. The hill chief of Gafumbegeti was arrested on accusations of collaborating with the Interahamwe.

On 20 July 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the village of Tagari in Dougoutene 1 Commune (Koro, Mopti). Village self-defense groups responded to the attack. No casualties reported, the Fulani gunmen seized livestock.

source: Le Pays Dogon; Undisclosed Source; Mali Jet
notes: On 20 July 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the village of Babouro in Dougoutene 1 Commune (Koro, Mopti). Village self-defense groups responded to the attack. Two Dogon men were killed and livestock seized by the Fulani gunmen.

actor2: Islamic State (West Africa) - Greater Sahara Faction
source: Al Naba; Armee Francaise; Undisclosed Source
notes: On 20 July 2020, French Operation Barkhane forces reportedly conducted an air-ground operation in the area of Tin Anor, Tessit Commune (Ansongo, Gao), killed four ISGS militants and arrested four others.
On 19 July 2020, two armed groups clashed near the village of Gouari (Bankass, Mopti). One Fulani fighter was killed in the clash.

source: Berger sahelien infos; Twitter; Undisclosed Source
notes: On 19 July 2020, Dozo militiamen attacked a position of other Dozo members in the village of Nienou (San, Segou), and killed 12 militiamen from the village. The attack came in retaliation for the murder of a Dozo chief three days earlier.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
source: Nyamilepedia; Eye Radio (South Sudan); PaanLuel Wel; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 19 July 2020, SPLM IO soldiers ambushed SSPDF in the Mapel area of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), in retaliation for the disarmament and arrest of their colleagues on 18 July. Two SSPDF soldiers were wounded in the ambush, whilst several SSPDF soldiers were reported to have been captured.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: On 18 July 2020, UPC combatants beat and held captive 1 FOCA solider in Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto). He was accused of having an affair with a combatant's wife. Local residents intervened to secure the release of the solider.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: On 18 July 2020, MINUSCA troops (Tanzanian battalion) clashed with 3R (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation) militiamen in Gbambia (Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei), following a military operation by the UN troops. The rebels were driven out from the village. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

Around 18 July 2020 (weekend of), clashes were reported between the Awan-Parek and Atok section of the Rek Dinka at an unspecified location in north-west Tonj North county (Warrap state, location presumed to be in the Awul area). At least 10 were killed and 19 wounded in the fighting.

On 18 July 2020, SSPDF clashed with NAS rebels at an unspecified location in Lobonok county, implied to be in the Karpeto area (Central Equatoria state). SSPDF claimed the event did not take place. There are no reports on fatalities or injuries.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
source: Radio Miraya; PaanLuel Wel; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 18 July 2020, SSPDF soldiers conducting a disarmament campaign disarmed and arrested several SPLM IO soldiers (including a Brigadier General) in the Jebel Teak area of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state; approximate coordinates from humanitarian source used). Reports indicate the IO soldiers have since been released.

On 18 July 2020, unknown raiders (presumed to be from Lakes state) attacked Agany and Wuncuei in Aluak-Luak payam of Yirol West county (Lakes state), killing one police officer and a civilian and wounding two others in a road ambush. The attackers also stole an unspecified number of cattle. Fatalities split across two events.

There is no clear motive for the attack.
On 16 July 2020, two unknown gunmen attacked a soldier in the city of Gao (Gao, Gao). The soldier overpowered and captured one gunman [a Sudanese national] while the second escaped.

source: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 16 July 2020, SSPDF clashed with NAS rebels at Lowe near Liria in Juba county (Central Equatoria state). NAS claimed to have killed 5 SSPDF, and inflicted 'many' injuries. On 16 July 2020, fighting was reported between Lou Nuer youth and Murle youth at Nanaam in northern Pibor county (Jonglei state), amid ongoing reprisal attacks in the area. There is no information regarding casualties.

On 16 July 2020, fighting was reported between Lou Nuer youth and Murle youth at unspecified areas in Pibor county (Jonglei state), amid ongoing reprisal attacks in the area. There is no information regarding casualties.

There are no reports of casualties or fatalities.

assoc_actor_2: Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
notes: Around 15 July 2020 (as reported), raiders (implied to be from Twic county, and accordingly presumed to be of the Twic Dinka clan) attacked three locations in the Mankien area of Mayom county (Unity state), including Kuel, Kuanydit and an unspecified location in the defunct Bul South county. At least 2 people were killed in clashes with local fighters (presumed to be Bul Nuer) and 5 wounded; 'many' were displaced in the clashes and 12-13 youth are missing, and 200 head of cattle stolen. The home of a spiritual leader was also attacked, and one of the attackers was captured.

Around 15 July 2020 (month of), two SSPDF were killed at an unspecified location in Northern Bahr el Ghazal state (presumed to be close to the border with Sudan) [coded to Maker] by Sudanese Misseriya pastoralists, amid increasing tensions between the Malual Dinka and Misseriya.

Around 15 July 2020 (as reported), three members of the organized forces (presumed to be SSPDF) were killed over a land dispute in the village of Boni Boni (presumed to be an alternative spelling on Abonbonyi, Jur River county) along the river Shargi of Western Bahr el Ghazal state in unclear circumstances. Note that the source does not specify whether the attack took place at Boni Boni or nearby Wau city, which is also mentioned in the source. The killers of the soldiers are presumed to be Luo militia.

Around 15 July 2020 (month of), armed youth from Kakor in Mvolo county (Western Equatoria) clashed with youth from nearby Alel village in Yirol West county, at an unspecified location (likely to be either Alel or Kakor) along the Mvolo/Yirol West border. The source notes that revenge killings and cattle theft occurred in the incident. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

On 14 July 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Sabelou (Bandiagara, Mopti), and the village self-defense responded to the attack. The assailants seized livestock. Casualties unknown.

source: Reuters; Le Pays Dogon; Undisclosed Source; Koro Kibaru; Mali Actu
notes: On 14 July 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Dangoboro in Madougou Commune (Koro, Mopti), and clashed with Dogon militiamen. Two Fulani and two Dogon men were reportedly killed.

source: AFP; aBamako; Undisclosed Source; Reuters; Mali Actu; Le Pays Dogon; Koro Kibaru
notes: On 14 July 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Intemeni (Bandiagara, Mopti), and clashed with Dogon militiamen. Four Dogon men were killed, and the attackers seized livestock.

source: Koro Kibaru; Le Pays Dogon; Reuters; Undisclosed Source; Mali Actu; Studio Tamani
notes: On 14 July 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Diankoudia [location unknown] in Madougou Commune (Koro, Mopti), and clashed with Dogon militiamen. Village self-defense reportedly repelled the attack. One Dogon man killed and two others injured.

source: Mali Actu; AFP; Reuters; aBamako; Koro Kibaru; Le Pays Dogon; Undisclosed Source
notes: On 14 July 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Monoboro, in Sangha Commune (Bandiagara, Mopti), and clashed with Dogon militiamen. Four Dogon men were killed, and the attackers seized livestock.

Around 8 July 2020 (as reported), the new administrator of the disputed Greater Pibor Administrative Area said that clashes were 'ongoing' at an unspecified location(s) in the Pibor area between Murle youth and unspecified attackers (likely either Lou Nuer and/or Bor Dinka). There is currently no mention of fatalities.
On 5 July 2020, Dan Na Ambassagou and Dogon militiamen clashed near the village of Berdossou (Koro, Mopti). No casualties reported.

On 5 July 2020, UPDF were reported to have 'kidnapped' two SSPDF soldiers on the South Sudanese side of the border, close to Nimule (Eastern Equatoria state). It is possible the apparent abductions are arrests which are related to a recent clash between SSPDF and UPDF on the Ugandan side of the border.

notes: On 4 July 2020, 'unknown gunmen' killed two Darfurian traders 2km east of Rumbek town (Lakes state) near an official checkpoint, prompting NSS agents stationed close to the site of the attack to fire upon the attackers, who fled the area.

On 4 July 2020, two unspecified sections of the Gok Dinka clashed at Madingkunyuk in Citcok payam of Cueibet county (Lakes state), killing at least four and wounding one. There is no further information.

source: Catholic Radio Network; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
notes: On 3 July 2020, suspected Murle raiders (operating alongside men in army uniform) attacked cattle camps close to Duk Padiet town in Duk county (Jonglei state), prompting a five-hour firefight with armed youth. 38 were reported killed and 44 wounded (one of whom died of their injuries over a week later), whilst over 20,300 head of cattle were reported stolen and five homesteads torched. An 11 year-old girl was also reported missing.

Around 3 July 2020 (between 3 - 4 July), unknown gunmen attacked the village of Batourou (Koro, Mopti), and killed a militiaman of the village self-defense who also was the son of the Bakaye village chief.

source: Kibaru; RFI; Reelle Afrique; Xinhua; Le Pays Dogon; Undisclosed Source; Nord Sud Journal; AFP; Reuters; AP; Mali Jet; AMAP; Studio Tamani; Koro Kibaru
notes: On 1 July 2020, suspected JNIM militants attacked the village of Gouari (Bankass, Mopti). Dogon militiamen defending the village were overpowered, and the attackers reportedly killed 16 people, burned the village, and seized livestock.

Around 1 July 2020 (as reported), two unspecified groups (both presumed to be inhabitants of the area) clashed in Citcok payam in northern Cueibet county (Lakes state), killing 4, and wounding 1. There is no further information.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Around 30 June 2020 (end of month), heavy fighting was reported between SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces in northern and eastern Baac payam in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), with at least 30 killed in the northern area (coded here as taking place in the Rumaker area) and at least 20 killed in the eastern area (coded here as Malualkon). An unspecified number of civilians were displaced.

On 30 June 2020, SSPDF clashed with unspecified armed youth (presumed to be inhabitants of the area) at an unstated eastern area of Tonj South county (Warrap state), as the soldiers were conducting a civilian disarmament campaign. 'Many' were killed, including at least 10 soldiers.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
source: Corbeau News; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Radio Ndeke Luka
notes: On 30 June 2020, during a two day battle, members of the 3R clashed with Bangladeshi MINUSCA soldiers at a checkpoint near Bocaranga (Bocaranga, Ouham Pende). A MINUSCA soldier was injured, and members of the 3R were killed. According to rumours, the leader of the group was killed, but such was denied by the group. Fatalities coded as 3 and split across two events.
On 30 June 2020, unknown gunmen clashed with Dogon militiamen in Fangadougou (Bandiagara, Mopti). Three Dogon were wounded.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Around 30 June 2020 (end of month), heavy fighting was reported between SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces in northern and eastern Baac payam in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), with at least 30 killed in the northern area (coded here as taking place in the Rumaker area) and at least 20 killed in the eastern area (coded here as Malualkon). source: Juba Monitor; VOA; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
notes: On 30 June 2020, armed youth from Paloc and Aduel payams of Rumbek East (and presumed to be Agar Dinka) attacked a cattle camp in Aluak-Luak payam in Yirol West county (Lakes state), in the Nyaruach area (note that one source says this was in the Mapuordit area). At least 9 were killed in the attack (1 SSPDF sergeant, 1 police officer, and 7 civilians, likely ethnic Atuot) and 2 women abducted. Hundreds of cattle were stolen, and an unspecified number of people displaced. Unconfirmed reports say 20 SSPDF were killed whilst pursuing the raiders; the army denies such reports.

source: Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network
notes: On 28 June 2020, during a three day clash, armed youth from the Padoch sub-section of the Apuk section of the Rek Dinka clashed with youth from the Buk (who appear to be a sub-section of the Atok section of the Rek Dinka) at the areas of Agany and Anyibuoth in Tonj North county (Warrap state), killing at least 32 (fatalities spread across three events) and wounding at least 7, whilst two villages were torched. The clashes are linked to the killing of a Padoch man in Awul in late May.

Around 28 June 2020 (weekend of), unspecified raiders clashed with unspecified armed forces (presumed to be army) at Gar cattle camp in Rumbek North county (Lakes state; coordinates for Agar used at GP2), killing 8 security forces personnel and 1 civilian.

notes: On 28 June 2020, armed Yiep youth from the Panyar sub-section of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka clashed with NSS personnel (either one officer, or several) in the Panakol area of Cueibet county (Lakes state), wounding one officer, who is reported to be from a rival section.

On 27 June 2020, Dan Na Ambassagou militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Berdossou (Koro, Mopti). Village self-defense responded to the attack, although nearly half of the village had been set ablaze. No casualties reported.

At least 33 were killed, and over 34 wounded. Security forces have since dispersed armed Gony, Dhiei and Kuei youth planning reprisal attacks.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims

source: Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network; Juba Monitor

On 24 June 2020, unknown gunmen attacked the village of Koira Beri (Douentza, Mopti), with village self-defense repelling the attack. No casualties reported.

On 24 June 2020, unknown raiders attacked a cattle camp in the Duk Padiet area in Duk county (Jonglei state), stealing around 1,000 head of cattle. Local youth caught the raiders and recovered around 450 cows, with one of the youth sustaining injuries in the firefight with the raiders.
On 23 June 2020, unknown gunmen attacked made an incursion into the village of Goundaka (Bandiagara, Mopti). Village self-defense routed the attackers. No casualties reported.

notes: On 22 June 2020, militiamen of the 3R (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation) clashed with a convoy of military soldiers, gendarmes and MINUSCA Forces in an ambush near Besson (Babua, Nana-Mambere). The ambush resulted in 5 soldiers killed, including a gendarme, and 10 injured. Six other soldiers went missing. The incident took place during the course of military operations against this militia.
On 22 June 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Gondogourou (Koro, Mopti), and clashed with Dozo militiamen. No casualties reported.

source: AMAP; Undisclosed Source; Nord Sud Journal; Essor; FAMAMali; Maliweb; Twitter
notes: On 22 June 2020, the Malian army entered the village of Nia-Ouro (Djenne, Mopti), killed between two and six alleged militants from a Fulani armed group, and recovered two weapons and two motorbikes. The army also arrested twenty people.

actor2: Islamic State (West Africa) - Greater Sahara Faction

An unspecified number of militants were killed and motorbikes destroyed. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

Around 21 June 2020 (as reported), Bor Dinka militia attacked White Army militia of an unspecified Nuer clan as they were moving stolen cattle seized around Gumuruk (clash presumed to have taken place north of the Gumuruk area of Pibor county, Jonglei state, along the route to Nuer home areas). 1 White Army militiaman was killed and 3 wounded in the firefight. The cattle had earlier been seixed from members of the Murle community.
On 21 June 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Omo (Koro, Mopti), and killed two Dozo militiamen.
On 20 June 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Manterou (Koro, Mopti), killed one Dozo during a clash with local militiamen, and seized a motorbike.
On 20 June 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Gangouroubourou (Koro, Mopti). Village self-defense repelled the attack. No casualties reported.

On 18 June 2020, an unidentified armed group clashed with police officers at the home of the Rutana chief of police in Rutana province. One police officer was injured.
On 18 June 2020, Dan Na Ambassagou attacked the Dogon village of Berdossou (Koro, Mopti) in an attempt to steal cattle. The village self-defense repelled the attack. No casualties reported.

Around 17 June 2020 (week of), Zande and Balanda militias reportedly clashed at an unspecified location in Tambura county (Western Equatoria state), killing 4. A local MP says that the conflict was related to power-sharing and representation in Tambura county, which may be linked to the peace process.

notes: On 17 June 2020, SSPDF and a local militia from Tambura county attacked SPLM-IO forces at their cantonment site in the area of Namutina (Western Equatoria state; note that one source says the camp was located closer to Tambura town, in the Nambiana area), killing an IO Brigadier General and at least ten IO soldiers. Tents in the camp were also torched. 5,646 people were displaced by the fighting.

source: South Sudan News Now; Juba Monitor
notes: On 17 June 2020, suspected Murle raiders clashed with local youths (including the Alian subsection of the Athoc section of the Bor Dinka clan, and other unspecified Athoc subsections) at Aliang in Bor South county (Jonglei state), with Bor youth repulsing the attackers and recovering cattle stolen during the clash. Five were killed and seven wounded.

On 17 June 2020, unknown gunmen attacked the prefecture in the town of Dire (Dire, Tombouctou), exchanged gunfire with guards, and wounded three civilians, including a child who succumbed to their wounds. The assailants abducted the subprefects of Dire and Dangha and seized two motorbikes. The subprefect of Dangha was released shortly after the abduction while the subprefect from Dire was released against ransom on 20 June.
On 16 June 2020, unknown gunmen opened fire against a Malian army checkpoint in Bourem (Bourem, Gao). The gunmen seized arms and a military vehicle. No casualties reported.

The UN reported that 'hundreds' had been killed and a local official says around 20,000 displaced to Pibor town in two weeks of fighting, while an unconfirmed report claims that 300 have been killed in fighting around June 14. One hundred fatalities coded across nine events covering a two week period.

The officer died of his wounds later after being arrested. The officer was attempting to violently obtain a plot of land from its owners, who had earlier refused to give it to him. Twenty have been arrested, including the six soldiers. UPDATE: a Brigadier General who was the former military attache to Uganda was arrested several weeks later in connection with the killing of the initial SSPDF MI perpetrator.

assoc_actor_2: Balanda Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Farmers (South Sudan)
notes: On 29 April 2020, militiamen from Tonj South county clashed with farmers from Kuajiena payam (presumed to be members of the Boor clan of the Balanda) at an unspecified location in Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal), likely close to the border with Tonj South. 3 Balanda were killed and 2 wounded; it is not clear whether there were fatalities from the Tonj militia. The fighting may be connected to a land dispute triggered by the establishment of two payams under the defunct 32 states system, which are no longer in effect.

Around 29 April 2020 (week of), armed youth from Tonj South attacked several villages in the Mapel area of Kuajiena county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), leading to clashes with residents of the area (presumed to be of the Boor clan of the Balanda). Three were killed, four wounded, and four villages torched. Thousands were displaced (one source says 'up to ten thousand' displaced).
Around 29 April 2020 (week of), armed youth (presumed to be Agar Dinka) killed a police officer and a civilian in Rumbek (Lakes state), amid a series of incursion into the town by feuding youth.

Around 29 April 2020 (between 26 April - 29 April), four were killed and three injured amid revenge killings between different Agar Dinka sections in the Rumbek area (Lakes state). There are no further details.

The FPRC, outnumbered, reportedly tried to fight the assailants and with MINUSCA support to protect civilians. The Government stated that 25 people were killed, including 21 civilians, while 51 were injured, but other sources reported at least 37 were killed.

source: Nord Sud Journal; Mali Jet; Maliweb; UN MINUSMA; Le Pays Dogon; Essor; Sahelien; Whatsapp; Bamada; Mali Actu
notes: On 28 April 2020, JNIM militants attacked a number of security checkpoints before assaulting the Malian army camp in the Kouakourou area (Djenne, Mopti). One civilian health worker was killed and around ten soldiers wounded in the attack. The militants seized vehicles, arms, and ammunition and burned the camp. A Malian air force intervention and airstrikes reportedly destroyed two vehicles, killed at least three militants and enabled the recovery of other vehicles, arms, ammunition, and equipment.

On 28 April 2020, Murle raiders clashed with armed pastoralists from Pamay cattle camp at an unspecified location in southern Uror county (Jonglei state), who were seeking to recover cattle stolen the previous day. 600 head of cattle were recovered; the source does not mention whether there were any fatalities in the fighting.

On 27 April 2020, arival armed youths (presumed to be Agar Dinka) clashed in the area of Cuei-Adukan in Rumbek Centre (Lakes state). A police officer was killed and another wounded during the clash under unclear circumstances. There is no mention of casualties or fatalities among the clashing youth groups, in what is implied to be a revenge attack among Agar sections.

On 27 April 2020, government troops (presumed to be SSPDF) clashed with NAS rebels at Rasul on the border between Maridi and Mundri West counties (Western Equatoria state), after the NAS were alleged to have looted civilians along the road between the counties, according to a local official. There are no reports of injuries. NAS rebels have denied the claims.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

On 25 April 2020, armed youth (presumed to be Agar Dinka) killed a police officer at the Abor-Jak/Mabor Jak cattle camp in Maboric boma of Rumbek East county (Lakes state). The police officer had intervened in an attempted theft being carried out by the youth.

On 24 April 2020, suspected Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon village of Sobane-Dognou, near Amani, Sangha Commune (Bandiagara, Mopti). Dan Na Ambassagou militiamen repulsed the assault. No casualties reported.

On 20 and 21 April 2020, attackers from Panyijar county (presumed to be Nyong Nuer) attacked a cattle camp at an unspecified location in Dok Nuer-inhabited Mayendit county (Unity state), leading to two days of fighting which resulted in 7 deaths and 4 wounded (fatalities spread across two events). 20,000 head of cattle were reported to have been stolen during the fighting.

On 11 April 2020, relatives of a cattle thief, who was killed the previous day, clashed with armed pastoralists responsible for his killing, likely in the area of Maleis and Mading Bor in Rumbek East county (Lakes state). 4 were killed, and 5 injured.

On 29 January 2019, fighting between Pakam youth and local youth groups at four locations in Eastern Lakes state (Yali; Pagarau; Machuor and an unspecified location in Rumbek Central), killing 16 (fatalities split across four events), and wounding at least 20. Soldiers tried to intervene in at least some locations; two soldiers were killed in the fighting, at unspecified locations (included in total toll).

Soldiers tried to intervene in at least some locations; two soldiers were killed in the fighting, at unspecified locations (included in total toll).

Soldiers tried to intervene in at least some locations; two soldiers were killed in the fighting, at unspecified locations (included in total toll).

Soldiers tried to intervene in at least some locations; two soldiers were killed in the fighting, at unspecified locations (included in total toll).

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: 27 January. Military forces were ambushed by rebels from the DRC in the Rukoko forest, Gihanga. Three soldiers were killed and others were seriously injured. Additional soldiers were deployed to the Rukoko Nature Reserve following the attack, while access to the reserve was banned.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: 27 January. An unidentified armed group from the DRC attacked a military position in the Rukoro forest, near Gihanga. Three soldiers were killed.

On 27 January 2019, two Ciec Dinka sub-clans clashed in the area of Majak-Jok (coordinates for Yirol, Lakes state, used). The Kuac-Dit clan were reported to have attacked the Kuac-Thii, as part of a series of attacks beginning November 2018. One Kuac-Dit fighter was killed.
On 26 January 2019, inter-communal clashes were reported in Ulang (Jonglei state). It is unclear who the attackers were, though actor2 has been coded as Eastern Jikany Nuer militia.
On 25 January 2019, unknown gunmen attempted to hijack a vehicle from a ranger in Douentza, one of the assailants was killed by a mob composed of security forces and locals and the second arrested.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 25 January. The UPC commander in Ippy executed the UPC soldier who killed 13 civilians the day prior.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
source: Radio Ndeke Luka; La Nouvelle Centrafrique
notes: 23 January. MINUSCA responded to a rocket attack by UPC forces. The groups clashed in the Hadji and Bornou neighborhoods of Bambari. Three civilians (including two children) were killed in the clashes.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
source: AMAP; Facebook; Telegram; Segou Infos; Studio Tamani
notes: On 21 January 2019, Katiba Macina (JNIM) militants carried out an attack against the Malian army and Dozos in the village of Toye, a soldier and a militant was killed, the militants seized a vehicle and weapons before withdrawing.

assoc_actor_1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
actor2: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-2020)
notes: On 20 January 2019, Ansar Dine (JNIM) militants launched a coordinated attack against MINUSMA positions in Aguelhok (Tessalit, Kidal). The attack was initiated by a suicide car bomb follow by armed assault, 11 Chadian peacekeepers were killed and 25 others wounded, at least three attackers were killed and one captured, JNIM claimed responsibility and said it was in response to the normalization of relations between Chad and Israel, the attack coincided on the day with PM Netanyahu's historic visit to N'Djamena.

On 20 January 2019, NAS forces claimed to have repulsed a government attack at an unspecified location along the Yei-Maridi road (implied to be on the Central Equatoria side of the road, and coded to Tore, Yei county, at GP2). NAS forces claimed to have killed three 'Mathiang Anyoor' (presumed to be a reference to Dinka SSPDF soldiers, and not to the presence of the former paramilitary force), and forced SSPDF soldiers to retreat.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
notes: On or around January 20th, NAS rebels claimed to have clashed with government forces in the area of Rokon (Central Equatoria). The NAS said they killed ten SSPDF soldiers, and captured ten members of the prison services, including a commander.

actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
notes: 20 January. Sidiki's 3R forces and armed Fulani attacked Zaoro Sangou, killing at least 13 people including two gendarmerie soldiers (some sources indicated 14 fatalities).

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: 19 January. Following the attack on two civilians by the UPC, MINUSCA and UPC forces in Bambari clashed in the Bornou and Elevage areas of the town. The UPC is reportedly hiding amongst the local civilian population in the city.

On January 18th (and/or January 17th, one event coded at time precision 2), NAS rebels claimed that government forces attacked their position at Mukaya payam (Central Equatoria). Unclear if NAS forces repulsed the attack, or retreated from their positions before besieging government forces. There are no reports of casualties.

On January 17th (and/or Jan 18th, one event coded at time precision 2), NAS rebels clashed with SSPDF soldiers at an unspecified location in Otogo county (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Luri used at precision 2). There are no reports of casualties.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

notes: 16 January. A joint MINUSCA-FACA force regained control of Bakouma after an early morning incursion into the town. Bakouma had been occupied by the UPC and FPRC since the end of December.
On 16 January 2019, NAS forces attacked SSPDF soldiers at their base in Jumbo (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties.

During the month of January, inter-communal clashes were reported at an unspecified part of Magwi county in the disputed Imatong state (Eastern Equatoria state, coordinates for Magwi town used at prec2), killing 7, and wounding an unspecified number. There is no further information, including on the identity of the groups (both coded as Imatong Communal Militias pending further information).

On 15 January 2019, presumed ISGS militants attacked the village of In-Ekar Ouest, seven MSA militiamen were killed in battle before the militants executed eighteen civilians of the Dawasahak community. Fatalities split between events.

assoc_actor_2: Tuareg Ethnic Group (Mali); GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group
notes: On 15 January 2019, presumed ISGS militants attacked the village of Amalaoulaou, and clashed with armed villagers, three village self-defense members and two other civilians were killed and three people were also wounded.

On 15 January 2019, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Tonj state) attacked Thakuer (Unity state, approximate coordinates used - some sources also point to Loat, Bul East county, Unity state). 28 people were killed in the attack, including five raiders in the ensuing fighting, and 58-60 wounded. 3,000 head of cattle were reported to have been stolen.

On 15 January 2019, presumed ISGS militants attacked the village of Taraterit (Taghatert), three MSA militiamen were killed in battle before the militants executed nine civilians of the Dawasahak community. Fatalities split between events.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 14 January 2019, presumed Katiba Macina (JNIM) militants clashed with the Malian army near Diafarabe, two soldiers wounded.

actor2: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
notes: On 14 January 2019, trucks travelling from Wau to Ater-Moc were ambushed in the area of Tonj (Warrap), seemingly by bandits. The source reports that a national security officer was injured in the attack (assumed on-duty), and that goods were looted from the drivers of the trucks. Several people have been arrested.
On 13 January 2019, an unknown individual stabbed a soldier in Douentza.

actor2: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: 13 January. Soldiers assaulted two Imbonerakure members in Kiyonza in retaliation for an attack on a soldier by Imbonerakure on 09/01.

On 12 January 2019, gold miners in the Farabacouta area of Sadiola barricaded roads, burned tires, and ransacked the gendarmerie, one individual was killed and four others wounded following clashes with security forces.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

source: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; AFP
notes: 11 January. Fighting between MINUSCA and security forces against the UPC continued in Bambari. France deployed two fighter jets over the city in a 'show of force.' MSF reported four wounded and one fatality during the day. Additional UPC fighters were reported around Bambari in the next days, entering the city in civilian attire and vehicles.
11 January. Military forces stationed near Munibhere (no coordinates available), between Sehe and Nyagumba shot at suspected rebels in the Kibira forest.

actor2: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 10 January 2019, French and Malian forces carried out a joint combined air-ground operation in the area of Dialloube, 15 presumed Katiba Macina (JNIM) militants killed.

10 January (on or around). Armed groups clashed in Bokagnan (coordinates are approximate based on location being 45 km east of Bouar, along the Bouar-Bozoum road). Over 1,000 residents were displaced.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

notes: 10 January. On a day of festivities in Bambari, the UPC launched attacks on the city and clashed with security forces. Two police officers and several UPC fighters were killed (unknown number on UPC side coded as 3).

On 10 January 2019, armed men attacked a truck carrying provisions the Dr John Garang University, in the area of Bed-Laku near Mangalla (Central Equatoria). A police officer who was accompanying the truck exchanged fire with the attackers, and was wounded in the process. The officer is to be taken to Juba for treatment.
On 9 January 2019, Fulani militiamen attacked the Dogon hamlet of Lorigan (coded as Koro at geoprecision 2), two villagers and one attacker killed.

actor1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)

On 8 January 2019, NAS and SSPDF forces were reported to have clashed in the vicinity of Yei (Central Equatoria).

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: On 7 January 2019, NAS and SPLM-IO rebels clashed at an unspecified location in Mugwo county (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Lu used at precision 2). Two NAS rebels died in the clash.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: On 6 January 2019, clashes occurred between an ex-Seleka group (likely the FPRC) and a group of Fulani herders near Birao (Birao, Vakaga). The clash occurred when the ex-Seleka group detained a herder for carrying weapons, they took the herder to the Geremandier. The detainees relative then stabbed one of the members of the ex-Seleka group, sparking a clash which left seven wounded.
05 January. During an attempted robbery, an armed group shot and killed a security guard at an NGO office in Batangafo.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

notes: 05 January (on or before). UPC/FPRC forces gained control of the village of Dimbe (no coordinate available), 5km from Bakouma (clashes assumed considering the presence of Anti-Balaka and military forces all around Bakouma).

On 5 January 2019, raiders suspected of coming from Western Lakes State attacked Kumuku cattle camp in Anuol county (Lakes state). In the ensuing confrontation, local militia (coded here as Eastern Lakes Communal Militia) received support from nearby soldiers, and repulsed the attack, killing ten raiders (unclear division of casualties). Two local fighters were wounded.

actor2: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: Around January 4 and 9, French and Malian forces carried out a joint combined air-ground operation in the area of Serma, 15 presumed Katiba Serma (JNIM) militants killed and 5 captured, a camp destroyed, and arms and equipment seized. Fatalities split between two dates.

On or around January 4th, youth from Geria and Ayaci counties (assumed armed) in the disputed Torit state fought at an unspecified location in Ayaci county (coordinates for Katire, Eastern Equatoria, used). Some houses burned down. There were no reports of casualties, nor of any details of the weapons used. The clashes were seemingly sparked over where the headquarters for Isore payam should be located.

actor1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
actor2: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: 03 January. Imbonerakure from Musenyi fought with Imbonerakure and a police officer in Mpanda, after the police officer had arrested one of their friends.

On 3 January 2019, government soldiers and NAS rebels clashed in the vicinity of Kitigiri and Onduraba in Central Equatoria (coordinates for the latter used). According to the NAS spokesman, 15 soldiers were killed, and one rebel died in the clash.

On 2 January 2019, raiders (suspected of coming from Boma state, and coded here as a Murle militia) attacked Pajimaar payam in Duk Pagak county (Jonglie state, coordinates for Pagak used at prec2). After what is described as a long battle, one local youth was killed, and 250 head of cattle stolen. Duk youth are pursuing the raiders.
On 2 January 2019, Malian authorities said that the army killed a presumed Dogon militiaman and arrested 24 others who were in the process of burning huts in the Fulani village of Bobosso.

source: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
notes: 02 January. Moussa Sair (Emperor), a ranking member of the KM5-Force militia was killed during a clash with LT, the leader of another KM5 militia. The clash occurred over the control of a parking area.
On 1 January 2019, a Malian soldier opened fire against his commander at the camp in Youwarou, but hit another soldier, he then attempted to desert, but was subsequently arrested.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
assoc_actor_1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 31 December. UPC and FPRC forces attacked Bakouma and clashed with Anti-Balaka and FACA forces. At least a dozen people were killed (coded as 12), including Sultan Madambari, who had ties to Anti-Balaka forces. Homes were burned and property was looted. Many of the residents fled as the UPC and FPRC took control of the town. Joint MINUSCA/FACA forces deployed the next day to initiate talks.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 30 December 2018, presumed Katiba Macina militants ambushed a National Guard patrol between Toubakoro and Sebete (coded as Sebete at geoprecision 2), two soldiers killed and two others wounded.

actor1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
notes: On 30 December 2018, armed prisoners escaped from Yambio Central Prison in Yambio (Yambio, Western Equatoria) and clashed with prison guards. Following the escape, unspecified security forces attacked the house of one of the escapees (a local musician), and shot him dead (recorded as one event).

On 30 December 2018, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed in the area of Kenyi in Lainya county (Central Equatoria), according to the SSPDF. The army spokesman accused rebels of initiating the attack; there are no reports of casualties.

On 30 December 2018, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed in the areas of Katigiri and Onduraba (Central Equatoria), according to the NAS, who also accused the army of dislodging them from their positions (note that there is no information on the location of Katigiri. Accordingly, one event has been recorded at Onduraba). There are no reports of casualties.

On 30 December 2018, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed in the area of Loka (Central Equatoria), according to the SSPDF. The army spokesman accused rebels of initiating the attack; there are no reports of casualties.

actor2: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group
notes: On 29 December 2018, presumed ISGS militants clashed with GATIA in Tinkarazeina near NTillit (coded as NTillit at geoprecision 2), the attack was repelled and a bag containing a detonator and wires seized by the militiamen who sustained one lightly wounded in their ranks.

On Dec 27th, NAS forces attacked an SSPDF base at an unspecified location in Wonduruba county (Central Equatoria state), reportedly in retaliation for the killing of a suspected NAS informant by government troops on Nov 23rd. Seven SSPDF soldiers were killed in the attack.

On December 26th and 27th, raiders attacked Luajang East and North counties (coordinates for Tonj, Warrap state used) in two separate events (one allegedly involving a group from the disputed Western Lakes state, and the other from the disputed Southern Liech state. There is no information regarding the date the different groups were said to have attacked). At least ten people died in the clashes, and 36 were wounded (fatalities split across the two events). 700 head of cattle were reported to have been stolen.

On 27 December 2018, cattle raiders (suspected of coming from Boma state, and coded as a Murle militia) attacked Akoi cattle camp in Twic Centre (coordinates for Wanglei, Jonglei state, used). One of the attackers was killed, and a member of the local youth militia was wounded.

assoc_actor_1: RRR: Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation; Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
source: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
notes: 26 December. Armed clash between herders allied to 3R and farmers in Bocarange after a dispute over land damage by their cattle. A gendarme who intervened during the clash was assaulted by the 3R chief.

On 26 December 2018, Luach-jang Dinka militia clashed with militia from the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka clan at an unspecified location in Aloor payam (Rumbek North county, Lakes state). At least 12 were killed (seven from the Pakam, and five from the Luanyjang), and 45 injured. It is unclear what triggered the clashes.

assoc_actor_1: Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
assoc_actor_2: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
notes: Around 26 December 2018, cattle raiders attacked Rek Dinka communities at unspecified locations in the disputed Luajang East and North counties in Tonj East county (Warrap state; coded to Romich) sparking two separate clashes. One clash was between Hah Nuer (presumed to be a misspelling of Haak Nuer) raiders and the Rek Dinka, killing five Rek Dinka. The other clash (involving members of the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka) has been coded separately. In addition to the fatalities, 36 were wounded, and 700 head of cattle stolen during the raids.

assoc_actor_1: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
assoc_actor_2: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
notes: Around 26 December 2018, cattle raiders attacked Rek Dinka communities at unspecified locations in the disputed Luajang East and North counties in Tonj East county (Warrap state; coded to Romich) sparking two separate clashes. One clash was between the Rek and raiders from the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka, which resulted in six fatalities (on the side of the Pakam). The second clash (involving Nuer raiders) has been coded separately. In addition to the fatalities, 36 were wounded, and 700 head of cattle stolen during the raids.
On 24 December 2018, Ganda Izo members entered the gendarmerie courtyard in Ansongo firing in the air demanding the release of an associate detained.

actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
notes: 24 December. 3R forces stormed the Gendarmerie base in Bohong and released two Chadian detainees.

source: Sudan Tribune; Radio Miraya; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
notes: On 23 December 2018, unknown gunmen abducted between seven and nine people in the area of Yari (Central Equatoria). A police officer travelling with the victims reportedly killed an attacker while four civilians were wounded.Local authorities accused NAS of being behind the attack, NAS denied.

On 23 December 2018, police fired upon one another at the Mobil roundabout in Juba, in unclear circumstances. One police officer was killed, and two wounded (one source states that three were killed, the lower estimate has been used here).

actor2: Military Forces of Mali (2013-2020) Operational Coordination Mechanism
notes: On 22 December 2018, unknown gunmen attempted to assassinate a Malian soldier part of MOC (mixed patrols) in Kidal, he escaped with injuries.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 22 December 2018, presumed Katiba Macina (JNIM) militants attacked the village of Dogo and killed a member of Dan Na Ambassagou, his son and wounded two others.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 22 December 2018, Katiba Macina (JNIM) militants carried out a complex ambush against a Malian army convoy in the area of Kera between Diafarabe and Tenenkou, at least two soldiers were killed and others wounded, a militant wounded, a vehicle destroyed, and a technical, arms, mortars, and computers seized.

At an unspecified time in the week beginning December 17th, two people were killed in a family feud in Kimotong county (Eastern Equatoria). One of the families was connected to a former local politician.

On 19 December 2018, French forces reportedly conducted an operation against presumed ISGS militants in the Gourma (coded as NDaki at geoprecicison 2), an individual abducted by the militants two weeks earlier was liberated but wounded in the process, he later succumbed to his wounds.

On 19 December 2018, French forces of Operation Barkhane conducted a combined air-ground operation 45km east of Akabar (coded as Akabar 45km E at geoprecision 2), and killed six ISGS militants and destroyed five motorbikes, U.S. equipment including a Glock 19 handgun and a laser sight seized by militants in Tongo Tongo was recovered.
19 December. A police officer was abducted in Ruhororo. The zone chief and eight others were arrested in connection with the abduction.
On 19 December 2018, an unidentified group attacked a location in the vicinity of Lol-Kou in Aweng county. Four fisherman and one soldier were killed in the attack.
On 18 December 2018, presumed Katiba Salaheddine militants attacked a camp in the area of Boutak, killing one individual, local self-defense retaliated, forcing the assailants to withdraw.
On or around December 18th, an SSPDF soldier from Waat base was killed in unclear circumstances at an unspecified location in Akobo county, according to the SPLM-IO.

source: Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 16 December 2018, NAS and SSPDF soldiers clashed in the area of Lobonok (Central Equatoria). Both sides accused the other of initiating the attack. The SSPDF said that two of its soldiers were killed and ten wounded; the NAS said that they had killed seven government soldiers and wounded ten (two fatalities coded), and captured a small number of weapons.

source: Sudan Tribune; Catholic Radio Network; Radio Tamazuj
notes: On 16 December 2018, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed twice in the area of Yei (Central Equatoria) and at an unspecified location close to the borders between Western and Central Equatoria, with both sides accusing the other of initiating the violence. The SSPDF spokesman said that NAS forces ambushed govt soldiers in the area (and also of destroying a bridge at Lumumba), killing two SSPDF soldiers and wounding five. The NAS said their forces were assaulted at two locations (Mile 13 and Mile 20 on the Yei-Maridi road), and that they had inflicted 'heavy losses' on the army (two events coded with one fatality apiece, with Yei at precision 2 as the location for one event, and Maridi (Western Equatoria) as the location for the second event, also at precision 2).

source: Catholic Radio Network; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj
notes: On 16 December 2018, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed twice in the area of Yei (Central Equatoria) and at an unspecified location close to the borders between Western and Central Equatoria, with both sides accusing the other of initiating the violence. The SSPDF spokesman said that NAS forces ambushed govt soldiers in the area (and also of destroying a bridge at Lumumba), killing two SSPDF soldiers and wounding five. The NAS said their forces were assaulted at two locations (Mile 13 and Mile 20 on the Yei-Maridi road), and that they had inflicted 'heavy losses' on the army (two events coded with one fatality apiece, with Yei at precision 2 as the location for one event, and Maridi (Western Equatoria) as the location for the second event, also at precision 2).

During the month of December, two Ciec Dinka clans (the Kuacthii and Kuacdit of the Manyiel section) clashed in the area of Nyang (Lakes state), killing six.

On 9 December 2018, a militia from Ajak Kuac county injured members of an unspecified group as they went to collect stolen animals at Unity state. The source does not provide further details, nor a precise location (coordinates for the disputed Twic State capital of Turalei (Warrap state) have been used at precision 3).

On 8 December 2018, cattle raiders shot dead a policeman guarding cattle, and wounded a trader. The event occurred at an unspecified location along the Mapel-Rumbek road (coordinates for Rumbek, Lakes state, used. Note that the source describes the event as taking place in the disputed Western Lakes state, meaning the attack would have occurred closer to Rumbek than to the towns of Tonj or Mapel, which are in the disputed Tonj state).

Some report of Ganda Izo involvement, who claimed its movement lost four Fulani combatants in the clashes (estimate likely less reliable).

On 5 December 2018, Dan Na Ambassagou militiamen surrounded the village Lessagou-Peuhl (coded as Lessogou at geoprecision 2) overwhelming the small self-defense group, and then killing 15 villagers. Coded as two separate events (one battle, one VAC).

notes: On 5 December 2018, SPLM-IO forces clashed with Taban Deng-aligned fighters in Bil in Guit county (Unity state), in clashes which lasted for three days (between 5 and 7 December), initiated by Taban Deng's troops. At least 21 people were killed (fatalities spread across three events).

On 4 December 2018, two Bul Nuer sections (the Jak and Thii) clashed at Kech near Bentiu town (Rubkona county, Unity state), resulting in 14 fatalities. The fight was allegedly sparked by the rape of a woman from the Jak section (coded in a separate event). According to the source, nine members of the Thii section (including one woman) and five members of the Jak section were killed.

source: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 2 December 2018, presumed Katiba Macina militants attacked a gendarmerie checkpoint in Kimparana, post destroyed, no casualties reported.

On 1 December 2018, Dozo militiamen attacked the village of Ouolon clashing with local Dozos, two were killed and three others wounded, two individuals including an elected official were reportedly abducted in connection to the events.

On December 1st and/or December 2nd, two armed Nyang Dinka sub-clans (the Kwac-thiin and Kwac-diit ) clashed at Kwacdiit (coordinates for Yirol, Lakes state, used), leaving four dead and seventeen wounded. The dispute appears to centre upon a grazing area.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 30 November 2018, Katiba Macina (JNIM) militants killed a customs officer and seized a vehicle belonging to the customs in Diema.

assoc_actor_1: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
notes: On 28 November 2018, presumed AQIM militants of the JNIM alliance clashed with Berabiche (Oulad Ghaylane) tribesmen in the Ezara zone.
On 28 November 2018, unknown gunmen ambushed a national guard patrol in the area of Fangasso, the soldiers returned fire but were forced to withdraw and abandoned a motorbike.

On 28 November 2018, ex-Seleka militia members attempted to rob a weapons cache from Anti-Balaka members in Batangafo town (Batangafo, Ouham) . An Anti-Balaka member was found killed after the incident, likely armed.

On 28 November 2018, SSPDF soldiers were ambushed by suspected Murle militia in the area of Kubal (note that Kubal is the name of a river; coordinates for Gumuruk, Jonglei state, used), killing three SSPDF troops. The soldiers had been pursuing cattle raiders who had been active in western Jonglei, and had recovered cattle, only to have the cattle stolen again by the armed youth who ambushed the soldiers.
On 27 November 2018, unknown gunmen attacked the gendarmerie in Hombori, one assailant was killed and four others arrested.

On 27 November 2018, two Malian soldiers under the influence of tramadol opened fire against each other at the interior of the army camp in Tarkint, one of the soldiers was killed and the other arrested, two vehicles were also damaged in the shootout.
On 25 November 2018, unknown gunmen shot dead a prominent business man with his driver and bodyguard in Gao. The guard was from the Ganda Izo group.
On 25 November 2018, in Bangui town (Bangui, Bangui), Mahamat Tahir, the leader of a Bangui militia was killed during an exchange of fire with a shop merchant who refused to obey his orders.

On 24 November 2018, a group of suspected local youth armed with sticks and machetes killed a soldier who intervened to protect a girl they came to attack. Eight suspects (four men, and four women) have been arrested in connection with the incident.

actor2: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 22 November 2018, French Barkhane forces carried out a combined air-ground operation between Farimake and Dogo (coded at approximate location as Gathi-Loumo 30km SW, geoprecision 2) resulting in the killing of 34 Katiba Macina militants including two senior commanders, as well as the probable death of the JNIM Emir of the Macina Region, Amadou Kouffa, according to an initial battle damage assessment.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 22 November 2018, UPC forces clashed with Anti-Balaka in Banangui (Zemio, Haut-Mbomou). Twenty-five homes were burned during the clash and thousands of residents fled.

notes: 22 November. Anti-Balaka forces attacked a MINUSCA post in the Alindao IDP camp. The combatants exchanged fire with the peacekeepers for 30 minutes before hiding within the camp. One civilian was killed and one was injured.

actor2: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group

On 20 November 2018, fire exchange in Bangui's PK5 area was reported. Although the source left the actors unidentified, it suggested that PK5 militiamen were likely to be involved.

On 20 November 2018, a police officer was shot dead by an unidentified group in Ngap county (coordinates for Cueibet, Lakes state, used). The attackers were suspected of coming from a neighbouring state, and were in the process of raiding cattle. The officer died as he was protecting a civilian from the raiders.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims

On 18 November 2018, Dogon militiamen (Dana Amassagou) attacked the village of Djabel (Dianwely) in the area of Kani-Bonzon, Fulani youths returned fire, several wounded.

On 18 November 2018, the Malian army attacked the village of Kologon where Dana Amassagou had settled, four Malian soldiers and four Dogon militiamen were killed in the clashes, five militiamen wounded and 15 arrested, motorbikes and at least one house were burned, and arms and ammunition seized.

On 17 November 2018, at 0200 GMT, unidentified gunmen attacked the HQs of Nimery Matar ('Force'), leader of the communal/vigilante PK5 militia, in the 3rd district of Bangui. Casualties were reported - unclear if fatalities or injuries.
On 17 November 2018, unknown gunmen attacked a Ganda Koy checkpoint in Temera, and killed one militiaman and seized his weapon.

On 17 November 2018, clashes were reported between unidentified groups in the Ouham region.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 15 November 2018, Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim civilians in the town of Alindao, prompting a reaction from UPC fighters. The UPC, along with members of a local militia calling themselves the Mujahedin, attacked an IDP camp hosting around 20,000 Christians which the Anti-Balaka operated out of. The UPC also brought civilians into the camps during the attacks, but it is unclear if they were used as shields to prevent a reaction from MINUSCA or if the civilians participated in the attack. The Anti-Balaka clashed with the UPC in the camp but ran out of ammunition, at which point UPC forces overran the site. At least 112 people were killed in these incidents (MINUSCA obtained in-depth information on at least 69 victims, while the rest of the names were given by local humanitarian organisations) , with no more precision about the nature of the dead (civilian or combatant) apart from two priests - fatalities split across three distinct events.

On 15 November 2018, an armed clash erupted within the Apuk Padoch Dinka clan in an unspecified part of Tonj state. 10 people were killed and seven wounded. Security forces arrested 25 suspects (the source reports the fight was sparked by a young girl being impregnated, leading to reprisal violence against the father's family).

At an unspecified time in November, three of Governor David Yau Yau's bodyguards were killed by an armed group (coded as a Murle militia), in or near Lukkuangole (Jonglei state). Yau Yau was reportedly attempting to secure the return of cattle stolen from western Jonglei, and three abducted children believed to have been taken from Lafon (Eastern Equatoria) at an unspecified time. Both the children and cattle were reclaimed.

On 11 November 2018, Dogon militiamen attacked the Fulani villages of Tancoulle and Tansamba, in Tansamba the attack was repelled, two villagers were wounded.

On 10 November 2018, two police officers were killed by an armed youth group in Bor (Jonglei state), coded here as two separate events occurring on the same day. After the first police officer was killed in Bor town, a youth who was arrested by the police escaped the police station in Bor, and his associates then ambushed and killed another police officer who was pursuing the escapee (wounding an additional police officer and two soldiers), at an area called Cuei-nyok located between Koch and Bor (coordinates for Bor used). By November 12th, three suspects had been arrested in connection with the ambush.

According to the county commissioner, 6,000 cattle were stolen, all of which were recovered.

On 5 September 2018, Turkana raiders from northern Kenya crossed the border to Lopul in Losolia county (Eastern Equatoria, coordinates for Narus used) and attacked a Toposa cattle camp. Initial reports stated that seven members of the camp (including non-combatants) were killed, whilst nine raiders were killed, and four wounded. However, local authorities revised the death toll upwards to 26, although they did not specify how many from the different groups were killed. They also reported that approx. 700 cows were seized by the raiders. The raid was reportedly in retaliation for a previous raid, and Toposa youth were said to have mobilised to reclaim the stolen cattle.

actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

On 31 May 2018, two factions within the Military Forces of South Sudan clashed in Uraj area in Mayom, Unity. Forces loyal to General Stephen Buay Rolyang fought against a group led by General Mathew Puljang after Gen. Buay had refused to cooperate with a military committee set up in Juba to meet him in Mayom. Gen. Buay (with 72 of his soldiers) was captured during the fighting and flown to Juba. Two soldiers of Puljang and five soldiers loyal to Buay were killed. Several others were reported wounded according to witnesses. The soldiers were released and returned to their units a month later, on or before 27th June, while two officers and General Buay remained under investigation.

source: Sudan Tribune; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Reuters
notes: Suspected rebels led by Col. Chan Garang Lual who defected to the SPLA-IO end October, attacked government positions at Gurei and Kapuri areas, west of Juba, leaving several killed. The group allegedly abducted an SPLA driver and forced him to show SPLA positions at gunpoint prior to the attack. One rebel was wounded in the clash while 50 government soldiers defected to their side. SPLA claimed seven rebels killed, one government soldier injured and denied the defections. The SPLA-IO military leadership later distanced itself from the fight, saying it was caused by disgruntled soldiers who defected in Juba and had not yet claimed their allegiance to their group. Hours before the fighting, authorities requested that the 3G network be temporarily shutdown across the country for unclear reasons.

source: UNSC; Radio Tamazuj; Gurtong Trust; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
notes: On 22 December 2017, armed pastoralists from the Nyara sub-subsection of the Abii section of the Bor Dinka clan clashed with pastoralists of the Biong, Mach-Ayiel, and Nyichak sub-subsections at or near Panwel or Pariak in Kolnyang payam (Bor South county, Jonglei state) killing 22 and wounding at least 18. The clashes appear to be related to either a dispute over the re-naming of Panwel (which was changed from Anuet), and/or a dispute over access to grazing land. 20 people, including five chiefs, were arrested for allegedly inciting the violence among the communities, and a buffer zone monitored by security forces was created to separate the parties.

In a statement on 5 November, the SPLA-IO official had claimed that SPLA-IO regained territory from NAS in Kajo-Keji, leaving 20 NAS killed. 20 NAS fatalities spread over two days of fighting in relevant areas; 14 killed in government and SPLA-IO clashes spread over Mangalotore and Logu. Local authorities said that two SPLA soldiers as well as two rebels (including a major) were killed in the clashes, alongside four civilians. Four other civilians were wounded, and four SPLA soldiers were also wounded. The rebels claimed to have inflicted dozens of casualties between this clash and another at Majak Wei (assumed to be in the same area), though these claims could not be independently verified, and the lower estimate of eight fatalities is used for one event coded to Malek Gumel.

notes: SPLA-IO rebels claimed to have recaptured Maiwut and destroyed military outposts around it on 7 August, a day after the government's capture of their Pagak stronghold, killing 'several' soldiers and stealing ammunitions. Several officials confirmed a brief recapture of the town by the rebels, while others including FVP Deng Gai, whose forces were involved in the fighting, claimed state forces were still in full control of the area.

assoc_actor_1: SPLM-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
source: Sudan Tribune; CTSAMM; Radio Tamazuj; AFP; Gurtong Trust
notes: Pro-government forces (SPLA and SPLA-IO led by Deng Gai) captured SPLA-IO's stronghold town of Pagak in Upper Nile. Both sides traded accusations over who started the clash: SPLA claimed it responded to an attack by the rebels on their positions in the area, and that SPLA-IO destroyed ammunition stores upon fleeing from the area and fired mortar rounds; the rebels claimed they were forced to withdraw after state forces launched ground and air attacks on the town.

Clashes between suspected pastoralists from Rumbek (Lakes state) and local youth in Maridi, along the Maridi-Rumbek road, left at least four people killed. Houses were looted and burnt down. The pastoralists attacked the area after unknown gunmen reportedly raided their cattle.

source: UNOCHA; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
notes: Clashes between unidentified rival armed groups at PK2 of Bria left one killed and one injured. Attacks on villages and tensions in and around Bria have continued to be reported following clashes between armed groups mid-June.

Around 5 August 2017 (as reported), local militia (presumed to be Gok Dinka) exchanged fire with armed youth (presumed to be Dinka) who were attempting to loot the primary school in Dhur village (Cueibet county, Lakes state). Casualties unknown.

assoc_actor_1: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Langdiing-Kongor-Gok Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Langdiing-Pagok-Gok Sub Clan Group (South Sudan)
source: Catholic Radio Network; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Gurtong Trust; Radio Tamazuj; UNMISS; Xinhua
notes: On 5 August 2017, the Waat (a Macar sub-section), and Kongor and Pagok sub-sections of the Langdiing branch of the Gok Dinka clashed with the Ayiel section of the Gok Dinka in Abiriu and Cueibet (Lakes state), killing at least 40 on both sides and wounding 53. In Abiriu, at least 9 were reported killed (fatalities split over two events).

In Cueibet town, at least 31 were reported killed (fatalities split over two events).
Clashes between armed groups at Karama village 7km of Alindao on 4 August left around ten killed and seven injured.

source: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; Xinhua; AP

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA claimed to have repulsed an attack by SPLA-IO rebels on oil fields north of Unity state in Tor-Abieth. Both sides claimed to be in control of the area. Casualty numbers vary. A local security official claimed that 22 rebels, 1 government soldier and 2 civilians were killed, while 11 others wounded during the clash. Rebels claimed dozens killed on the government's side, 2 on theirs, and several others injured. They also claimed that several civilians in military barracks were injured and captured.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: On 3 August 2017, SPLM-IO rebels attacked a government base in Tayandaw village (Longchuck county, Upper Nile state). Casualties unknown.

source: CTSAMM; Sudan Tribune; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
notes: Five people were killed (including a national security officer, three South Sudanese and an Ugandan national) and 13 others injured in an ambush by unknown gunmen along the Juba-Nimule highway, in the Moli area. Soldiers escorting the civilian convoy exchanged fire with the gunmen, killing two of them. A baby was unaccounted for after the attack, with the parents suspecting other passengers to have taken him towards Nimule during the confusion.

actor2: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
source: UNOCHA; RFI; MSF; AFP; Radio Ndeke Luka
notes: FPRC and Abs forces clashed after several motorcycles' thefts over 29 July-2 August. 24 dead, including 14 civilians, 17 wounded including 3 civilians, 221 shelters burnt down and several houses looted. Several NGO compounds were also looted during the fighting and their headquarters occupied by the Abs. 10,000 people were displaced.
Renewed violence between Dogons & Fulanis in Koro, Mopti Region. 1 Dogon killed, 2 wounded & 1 taken prisoner. Dozos from Ke-Macina were said to be en route to reinforce the Dogons.
Unknown assailants riding motorbikes ambushed a group of Malian forces at a water source in Almoustarat, killing two.
Cattle keepers clashed with armed men who came to raid their cattle in Kidepo/Kimotong area of Kapoeta state. More than 20 people died in the clash, while 300 herds of cattle were taken.

On 2 August 2017, clashes were reported between Mabanese and youths from Melut county (presumed to be Ageer Dinka) at Kilo 10 (Melut county, Upper Nile state), over a border dispute. Casualties unknown.

Angry youth exchanged fire with the Twic State governor's security guards at a meeting in Turalei. They accused the governor of taking sides over the leadership of Wunrok County. Several youth along with the former governor of Twic state - whom authorities accused of inciting the violence - were arrested.
A Malian army convoy was ambushed between Gossi and Hombori. No reported casualty.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition

They also claimed to have destroyed a convoy which had come from Lui to rescue the government soldiers. Date is unclear. Report dated 31 July. According to humanitarian sources, dozens were killed, including civilians.

notes: SPLA-IO forces under FVP Deng Gai gained control of Maiwut town on 27 July after two days of heavy fighting with rebels allied to Machar. Rebels admitted only two soldiers killed and five others wounded from their side. Rebels denied the capture of Maiwut and claimed reinforcement arrived the following day, on 28 July, to halt pro-government troops' advancement.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
source: UNOCHA; Sudan Tribune; South Sudan News Agency
notes: Reports of government offensives on SPLA-IO positions in and around Mathiang in Longochuk County, Upper Nile, from around 1-6 July. On 6 July, SPLA-IO claimed to have repulsed pro-government attacks on their positions in Mangok, Mathiang, Malou, Biot and Guel Guk, inflicting 74 fatalities and dozens of injuries. Meanwhile, government troops claimed to have captured Marial and Thoc areas in Longochuk, losing five soldiers and 21 others wounded. Thousands of people were displaced and dozens of aid workers forced to relocate from Longochuk and Maiwut counties as tensions escalated around 6-7 July. Humanitarian compounds in Mathiang were reportedly looted during the fighting. SPLA denied any clashes in the area.

source: Sudan Tribune; Gurtong Trust; Radio Tamazuj
notes: On 14 June 2017, SPLM--IO rebels reported to have clashed with government forces (supported by unspecified militias) in the areas of Moti and Iholong in Torit county (Eastern Equatoria state) and Ayiri (assumed to be an alternate spelling of Iyiri, Magwi county). Rebels claimed government forces attacked their positions in the state, but that they repulsed them killing 16 and wounding 17. Other numbers give 28 fatalities on SPLA-IO's side and 7 on the side of the government (lower fatality estimate of 16 used, which is distributed across three events). The SPLA have disputed the claims made by IO rebels, though have acknowledged that rebels ambushed a military patrol south of Torit town on 14 June.

notes: Clashes between SPLA-IO and Mathiang Anyoor militia in Matot, Pieri, Pulchuol, Waat and Walgak areas of Jonglei on 15 April. State forces reportedly recaptured Waat after two days of fighting on 15-16 April. In Waat, rebels claimed that government forces dropped poisonous gas from helicopters during the attack, targeting rebel positions, leaving several people injured. Civilians who fled the area alleged initial indiscriminate shelling and shooting by government forces and cross-fire from opposition forces, causing deaths of civilians. Property was also looted and destroyed during the fighting. Humanitarian workers were forced to evacuate the area.

The source states that IO forces deserted the area during the fighting, with this event coded on the assumption that IO forces were in control of the area prior to the fighting. Casualties unknown.

Two incidents of clashes between herders from Tonj State and farmers from neighbouring Wau State between 12-14 April left at least four killed and two wounded in Kwarjina area, which borders the two states.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between government and SPLA-IO forces around Yuai in Jonglei on 12 April. Local residents accused government troops of committing atrocities against civilians on the side of the fighting, resulting in killings and burning down of houses. Rebels said 17 civilians were killed by SPLA in Yuai. SPLA denied any clashes in the area.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: JNIM claimed an ambush against a Dozo convoy in Ke-Macina, Segou, killing and wounding several (fatalities coded as 3).
Government forces launched an offensive against various militias in Pajok and Ayaci, Imatong state. Over 4,000 people fled to Lamwo District in Northern Uganda.

Clashes between Dinka Agaar and Dinka Atuot tribes over a cattle raid that had earlier occurred in Rumbek East. The clashes occurred around Mvolo in Western Equatoria and left seven killed. Further cattle raiding incidents between the two groups were reported in April.

actor1: Mutiny of Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
actor2: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
notes: Clashes between prison guards in Wau as four of them mutinied left two killed. The mutineers fled.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between SPLA-IO and government forces near Wau town left five SPLA soldiers killed. Upon their return from the clashes, SPLA-IO rebels ambushed an SPLA convoy, killing two senior SPLA officers (the 5th division's head of operations and his counterpart for logistics) and their 12 bodyguards. This sparked tensions and violence in the town.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: In Central Equatoria, confrontations between Government forces and the pro-Machar SPLA in Opposition were reported in Ombaci, Yei County, on 8 April. No mentioned fatality.

actor2: CJA: Congress for Justice in Azawad

notes: A MINUSMA-chartered truck was attacked by unidentified gunmen between Gao and Gossi. No casualties reported.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between government and SPLA-IO forces spread to Baggari, SPLA-IO's stronghold, after an earlier clash outside Wau. Government forces reportedly re-captured the town from the opposition, though rebels denied it. No mentioned fatality.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: On 8 April 2017, SPLA-IO and SPLA clashed in Bazia. After the fighting, SPLA reportedly followed the rebels to their stronghold in Bagari, allegedly taking control of the area.

actor2: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad (CMA)

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition

actor2: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims

source: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Catholic Radio Network
notes: Unknown gunmen ambushed a convoy carrying IDPs from Juba to Pibor at Sirkat, just 10km east of the capital, leaving at least four people killed and 13 injured. source: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Reuters; Sudan Tribune; UN HRC; UNMISS
notes: On 3 April 2017, SPLA and SPLA-IO clashed in Liro area of Pajok, leaving at least 18 killed, including four civilians. SPLA soldiers allegedly arrested and killed at least 22 civilians in the town in subsequent raids carried out until 5 April, mostly from the Acholi group, as well as raped civilians and looted and destroyed property, forcing thousands of people to flee for safety across the nearby Uganda border. UNMISS reported up to 66 killed but a later report by the UN Human Rights Commission on South Sudan claimed only 22 deaths could be corroborated.
