actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Around 1 April 2017 (beginning of month), government forces (assumed to be SPLA) attacked the market at Jalimo (Kajo Keji county, Central Equatoria state), which at that time was under control of the SPLM-IO. Four civilians (including a farmer) were killed, and one IO fighter was also killed.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA-IO claims to have repulsed a government attack on their positions in Kurgulu area of Kajo Keji. No mentioned fatality.

notes: Police Officer Simon Masumbuko was abducted. The Police Chief of Kobero and a National Intelligence Officer have been arrested.

notes: Clashes between SPLA-IO and government forces in Kuku villages in and around Kajo-Keji and on the Juba-Kajo Keji road, leaving 14 soldiers killed and armaments stolen. SPLA denied the clashes. SPLA-IO reportedly raided a prison in the area during the clashes, freeing dozens of prisoners.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: On 26 March 2017, UNMISS conducted a patrol to Mayendit, where pro-Machar SPLA in Opposition officials reported clashes with Government forces.

Malian soldiers raided Kouakourou in the Kewa area and clashed with alleged Islamist militants, killing 10. At least 8 other alleged Islamist militants were arrested, while 30 others were also reported arrested (not clear if they were also militants or just suspected of affiliation).
Unidentified assailants clashed with security forces in the Boni area.
3 people were killed and 4 wounded in an attack by unidentified assailants on a Malian army post in Almoustarat. Vehicles were also seized by the attackers.

At least 3 people were killed at Diaka in Tenenkou Cercle in fighting between Fulani and Bambara.

Clashes between Murle youth groups belonging to the Lango and Kurene clans on 21-22 March in Pibor. No reported fatality. Persisting tensions the following day forced hundreds of civilians to seek protection at a former PoC site. However, a meeting led by the local governor solved differences between the two groups and avoided new clashes.

They were all released four days later. Military officials initially accused SPLA-IO rebels, but the rebels denied the claim, saying they were controlling the area.

Clashes between armed groups in Atar, Pigi county, early March, leaving more than 5,000 people displaced. Clashes reportedly involved killings, destruction of property, gender-based violence and recruitment of children by armed actors in the affected areas.

Clashes between armed groups in Pagil area of Ayod in Jonglei, causing many civilians to flee to the bushes and neighbouring counties and forcing aid actors to relocate. Clashes were reported in the Ouham-Pende localities of Pende and Santouwane between RRR and Anti-Balaka fighters. As many as 6 RRR fighters were killed in these clashes, and 2 Anti-Balaka fighters seriously injured. The fatalities were disaggregated between the two locations. The coordinates for Santouwane are approximate, based on information provided in an ACF report.

Clashes were reported in the Ouham-Pende localities of Pende and Santouwane between RRR and Anti-Balaka fighters. As many as 6 RRR fighters were killed in these clashes, and 2 Anti-Balaka fighters seriously injured. The fatalities were disaggregated between the two locations.

Government forces intercepted armed men when they attacked government positions in Torit. No casualties reported.

notes: Battles between Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement and Agwelek forces in northern Manyo county over 3-4 January. NDM claims to have killed more than 25 Agwelek forces while Agwelek claims to have killed 37 NDM, including two generals.

Around 3 January 2017 (as reported), clashes between the disputed Ruweng and Northern Liech (presumed to be Ruweng Dinka and Leek Nuer, respectively) took place in the area of Kaljak (Rubkona county, Unity state), killing at least 15 people. The violence appears to relate to the placing of the administrative boundary between the two disputed states.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
notes: Suspected SPLA-IO forces clashed with SPLA along the Torit-Juba road, west of Torit town, killing three SPLA soldiers and injuring two others. On the same day, suspected SPLA-IO elements also attacked a prison facility along the Torit-Magwi road, south-west of Torit town, leaving six prison guards missing.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between government and SPLA-IO soldiers in several areas of Nasir on 2 January. Government forces attacked and took Ketbek. They also attacked northeast towards Kuatt, north towards Haimajak and reportedly east towards Ebone. The fighting resulted in homes looted and razed, damaged UNMISS property (accommodation containers and an armoured personal carrier) and forced displacement of around 33,000 people. No mention of fatalities.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between government and SPLA-IO soldiers in several areas of Nasser on 2 January. Government forces attacked and took Ketbek. They also attacked northeast towards Kuatt, north towards Haimajak and reportedly east towards Ebone. The fighting resulted in homes looted and razed, damaged UNMISS property (accommodation containers and an armoured personal carrier) and forced displacement of around 33,000 people. No mention of fatalities.
Unidentified gunmen attacked the Malian gendarmerie in Gossi. The gendarmerie offices and a hanger were set on fire during the attack.

The Governor of Lol, one of South Sudans newly created states, narrowly escapes an assassination attempt by unidentified gunmen near Raja. There are no injuries from the exchange of fire between the gunmen and the governors escorts.

On 30 December 2016, Jur Bel youth clashed with Gok Dinka youth at an unspecified location (presumed to be along the Cueibet-Wulu county borders in Lakes state, and coded to Bahr Gel), killing 15 people. The reason for fighting is not specified.

actor1: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
notes: Suspected SSPPF members ambushed an SPLA convoy at Rimenze Boma, north-east of Yambio town, leaving 2 SPLA soldiers killed.

On 28 December 2016, clashes resumed at Doro refugee camp (Maban county, Upper Nile state) between 'the host community' (presumed to be Mabanese) and refugees (presumed to be Uduk), following intense clashes on 24 December. Casualties unknown.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: On 26 December there were heavy clashes between Government and SPLM/A-IO forces. About 100 Government soldiers and three vehicles were seen advancing from their base, past the UNMISS base and towards the SPLM/A-IO positions in Kedbeck to the east of Nassir. Heavy fighting was heard.

A clash between two youths, which resulted in one dead, led to a larger gunfight in Batangafo. Few details were reported but it seems the fight may have happened in a stronghold of ex-combatants of the Seleka coalition. The source said it did not hold any reliable information to confirm whether the ex-Seleka had fired shots.

On 25 December 2016, militia (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and presumed to be Murle) clashed with local militia (presumed to be Twic East Dinka) after they attacked Bapiny (presumed to be a misspelling of Baping) village in Twic East county (Jonglei state). At least seven people were killed, including two of the attackers, and an unspecified number were wounded.

On 25 December 2016, Maban Defense Force militia attacked Bunj (Maban county, Upper Nile state), clashing with refugees from Blue Nile state (presumed to be predominantly Uduk, given their involvement in violence at Doro the previous day). Subsequent reports state that at least 70 people were killed in the violence. Around 1,600 refugees were re-displaced to Blue Nile state following the violence in Doro and Bunj.

actor1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
notes: Clashes between NSS police officers deployed to ensure security in Yei and SPLA-affiliated armed group on the Yei-Maridi road (2km from Yei), resulting in the death of two pro-government soldiers.

On 24 December 2016, Maban Defense Force militia under the command of Johnson Khalifa attacked Doro refugee camp (Maban county, Upper Nile state), clashing with Uduk refugees. Subsequent reports state that at least 70 people were killed in the violence (the majority of those killed being refugees), though the militia leader was among the dead. Around 1,600 refugees were re-displaced to Blue Nile state following the violence in Doro and in Bunj the following day.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition

In the afternoon about 100 armed civilians and SPLM/A-IO soldiers were seen advancing towards Nassir from the east before withdrawing. Clashes continued on 26 November.

SPLA-IO repulsed the government forces to the nearby Wadekona town and stole armaments.

Machar confirmed the clashes but denied that his forces were the ones to attack. Dozens of people fled to neighbouring Uganda.

Inter-clan clashes between the Gak and Manuer sections of the Dinka tribe in the Rual Nuer and Amuok areas of Rumbek North County in Western Lakes State left at least 22 people killed and 41 wounded over two days. Fighting started after the killing of a man at a cattle camp two days prior and the fatal beating of a dog at Rual Nuer area.
Clashes between militiamen led by Abelbagi Ayii and government forces in Aweil East State left three soldiers dead and five others captured.

Inter-clan clashes between the Gak and Manuer sections of the Dinka tribe in the Rual Nuer and Amuok areas of Rumbek North County in Western Lakes State left at least 22 people killed and 41 wounded over two days. Gunmen fired on a bus carrying the Torit youth football team at Lolere village near Torit town, wounding six players and reportedly killing the driver. Police exchanged fire with the gunmen and managed to rescue most of the players.

notes: Unknown gunmen attacked SPLA barracks in Ezo county but were repulsed by the government forces supported by UNMISS and fled after looting several properties. At least six rebels were killed, and hundreds of civilians were displaced.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Mali (2013-2020) Prison Guards
source: Maghreb Emergent; AP; Long War Journal; AFP; Twitter
notes: A policeman and a Malian prison officer were missing Monday, allegedly abducted, after an attack by Ansar Dine on the night of Sunday to Monday against the Malian town of Banamba. Two vehicles of the Gendarmerie were seized by the gunmen. According to the sources, the attackers arrived in Banamba 'aboard a dozen vehicles' were immediately divided into three groups. One group attacked the local gendarmerie, another group attacked the jail to free prisoners, and a third headed a bank on site to force the safe. 21 inmates were released from a prison. One of the two missing men was found on Nov. 8 while the second on Nov. 9.

Ansar Dines forces attacked a military camp in Gourma Rhaous, in Tombouctou, burning military equipment and temporarily taking control over the outpost. Additionally, the group claimed to capture 5 vehicles, burned another 6, and captured at least one DShK machine gun. It also reported that one of its own fighters was killed in that attack.

notes: A UN peacekeeper from Togo and two Malian civilians were killed Sunday at around 10:30 am (1030 GMT) when a MINUSMA logistics convoy was the target of a complex attack 45 kilometres (30 miles) north of Douentza, in the Mopti region. After a mine or improvised explosive device was detonated and the attackers opened fire on the convoy. Many sources reported Ansar Dine has claimed the responsibility while on Nov. 8 the Al-Akhbar website reports El Mourabitoune has also claimed responsibility for detonating a bomb that targeted Malian army truck although there are no more confirmations about.

Unidentified armed men attacked farmers on their way to their farms in el-Ghalak in Eastern Nile State, killing six and abducting at least seven women and children. A police officer and two of the attackers were killed in ensuing clashes between the two groups. The attackers were seen driving to the border with Sudan.

Report of clashes between unidentified gunmen and SPLA forces in Chukudum, Eastern Equatoria over seven days. By 13 October, the gunmen were reported to have gained control of several parts of the town, where SPLA forces had to retreat. Fatalities were reported though unknown number - spread 10 over the seven days of fighting. Almost all schools operating in the town were closed as a result of the clashes.

actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: The commander of CARs army (FACA) was killed and his son injured in an attack by a militia led by Abdul Danda in the PK5 neighbourhood in Banguis 3rd district leading to unrest in the city. Abdul Dandas militia have allegedly been involved in numerous abuses against civilians according to the COMUC. After the death of the commander, FACA soldiers attempted to arrest members of Abdul Dandas militia, resulting in 2 self-defense fighters killed and injuries to 4 soldiers. MINUSCA forces intervened to separate the two armed groups. Abdul Danda later died his groups involvement.

Following the death of the commander of CARs army, self-defense militias in PK5 erected barricades to prevent entry/exit to the district where the commander was killed. Violence broke out in this area as well as the 3rd (where PK5 is located), 5th and 6th districts of the capital, resulting in a number of injuries. 3 Fulani farmers were reported killed in retaliatory violence during the unrest. MINUSCA forces intervened to end the clashes in the various districts. According to MINUSCA, in total 11 people were killed, 14 are missing, and 11 were injured during the violence (5 fatalities not coded in other events spread across the 3 districts).

Fighting in Lafon town on 8 and 15 August between SPLA and armed groups. On 8 August, armed groups reportedly gained control of the town, while on 15 August, SPLA came to retake the area from them. During the violence, reports of mistreatment of civilians by armed groups, forced recruitment by armed groups as well as forced displacement, abductions, sexual violence and heavy looting of nutrition supplies, medicines, schools and houses. The entire population of the town was displaced and as of four months later, only half had returned.

Gunshots of unknown origin heard. According to a police source, it was due to a group of gunmen with rifles who were trying to ambush cars on the road Bujumbura-Ijenda. According to the same source, the military intervened and the men have retreated into the mountains overlooking the Ruyaga area. No human damage was reported.

notes: Around 35 heavily-armed former Seleka rebels were intercepted by MINUSCA in Sibut, resulting in 2 Seleka fighters killed, some injuries, and 10 captured. These were allegedly part of the group affiliated with the FPRC which illegally left Bangui the night before.
Heavy fighting between unidentified groups erupted in Gulumbi payam shorty after a government delegation left the area, causing civilians to flee the area.
2 SPLA soldiers were killed in an ambush by gunmen on the Khor Dababa area of Bor-Juba highway over the weekend.

45 people were killed and dozens injured when armed youth, allegedly from Koch county, clashed with government forces in Tharjiathbor county of Unity state. At least some of those injured were humanitarian workers.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: An SPLA-IO spokesman claimed government forces attacked their positions in Adok Al Bahar area near Leer. The spokesman accused the attackers of killing 2 men, raped 15 women, and looted property including 50 cows.

SPLA forces and unidentified armed men clashed in the Kimba Payam of Morobo County. The fight started near a funeral, resulting in fatalities among both the civilians and armed men (coded as 10). The SPLA forces repulsed the attackers.

At least 3 people were killed in an alleged attempted assassination by unidentified assailants against the governor of Gdudue as his convoy traveled through Yambio. At least 3 of the governors bodyguards were also injured, while the governors military escort successfully fought off the attackers.

24 SPLA soldiers and 22 civilians, including the Mayendit county commissioner, were killed and 30 injured in an attack by unidentified gunmen in the Rubkuai area of Mayendit. About 6,000 head of cattle were also taken. The attackers were allegedly from Koch county.

Fighting in Lafon town on 8 and 15 August between SPLA and armed groups. On 8 August, armed groups reportedly gained control of the town, while on 15 August, SPLA came to retake the area from them. During the violence, reports of mistreatment of civilians by armed groups, forced recruitment by armed groups as well as forced displacement, abductions, sexual violence and heavy looting of nutrition supplies, medicines, schools and houses. The entire population of the town was displaced and as of four months later, only half had returned.

Thousands flee a battle between the military and an unnamed armed group. No casualties reported.

The communal administrator intervened but was unable to prevent the Imbonerakure from beating up the police officer.

notes: Sporadic clashes between government and opposition forces in piliny area near Leer over 13-15 July. Many casualties reported.
Inter-communal clashes between Panawur and Panaguong sections of the Dinka tribe in Cueibet area in July left 14 people killed on both sides. Motive is unclear.
The morning after an LRA attack in Kpata, some youths from the village pursued the LRA rebels and killed 3 of them.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Sporadic clashes between government and opposition forces in piliny area near Leer over 13-15 July. Many casualties reported.

Unknown gunmen ambushed a government military convoy in Mitika, south of Yei, leaving 17 SPLA soldiers killed. After the incident, soldiers returning to Yei joined by armed Dinkas killed four local civilians, including a shop owner in the Dar es-Salam market.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Sporadic clashes between government and opposition forces in piliny area near Leer over 13-15 July. Many casualties reported.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
source: Amnesty International; Centre for Civilians in Conflict
notes: In the course of fighting between SPLA and SPLA-IO forces near the UN base in Jubas Jebel area, the two parties fired indiscriminately. A large number of bullets, high-calibre weapons and shells struck the two POC sites in the UN base, leaving at least 50 civilians inside the POC sites killed between 10-12 July, including around 30 on the 10th, more than 160 injured, including UN staff, and causing significant property destruction, including to International Medical Corps maternity ward and to the tents of many NGOs operating in the base. In the course of the fighting, two Chinese peacekeepers were also killed and another six peacekeepers were injured by shelling while patrolling in the vicinity of the UN Jebel HQ on 10 July.

actor2: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition

Gunfire reported in Wau town. The violence is reported to involve SPLA soldiers firing at one another.

Two Malian soldiers were killed on Saturday 9 July following an attack by armed men 'wearing turbans' in a locality near the border with Burkina Faso. source: UN HRC; Radio Tamazuj; Al Jazeera
notes: On 24 and 25 June, soldiers and police joined armed Dinkas in a clash with armed youth from the Fertit community in Wau. SPLA soldiers deliberately targeted civilian populations and looted hundreds of shops and huts. Between 39-69 bodies were collected and recorded by the police as having been killed, including at least 15 women and 10 children. It is unclear how many of the fatalities were deliberately targeted and how many died in the crossfire. Fatalities split between battles and violence against civilians events.

On 14 and 15 June, an unknown armed group attacked the SPLA and government offices in Raja town resulting in fighting with the SPLA. The gunmen took control of the town for several hours, but JEM reinforcements arrived and re-captured the town. At least 35 soldiers killed, including governors bodyguards, and 13 wounded. Government vehicles attempting to leave the city were ambushed and burnt, while Red Cross vehicles were looted. Reports that tribal leaders in the area have rejected President Kiirs proposed creation of Lol State, although identity of attackers remains unconfirmed.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Military and armed men loyal to Machars SPLA/M-IO clashed in Kansuk of Kajo-Keji county. 21 soldiers killed, dozens wounded on both sides. Reports of 3 civilians also killed. 1500 displaced. Clashes supposedly sparked when soldiers did not want to pay for goods from sellers in the market, and opposition forces loyal to Machar saw the verbal disagreement between soldiers and merchants and decided to intervene with force. Reports that during the fighting, army units from Juba and from Mundari in central Kajo-Keji were sent as reinforcements. Both were ambsuhed en route to Kansuk, with unknown number of people killed in the ambush on the Mundari unit. Fatalities for events in Kansuk and Mundari (Kansuk coordinates used) is 34 (21 soldiers, 3 civilians, and 10 coded for unknown number of lives lost in road ambush near Mundari).

14 people described either as former Seleka and arned Fulani were killed during a clash with 'internal security elements' (described as a self-defense group in another article) in the city of Bang in the Ngaoundaye area. Negotiations had been ongoing with the Fulani to enter the city with their flocks but without their weapons, but they refused to disarm, which resulted in the clash after 3 armed Fulani youths were arrested in the morning. The commander of the brigade which opposed them and other members of the security forces were wounded in the gunfight.

source: AFP; UN (unspecified); Deutsche Welle; Al Jazeera
notes: On 7 August 2015, gunmen attacked a Malian military site in Sevare (Mopti, Mopti). The attack was repelled and the gunmen instead stormed and sieged a hotel, taking several hostages. Malian military forces intervened to free the hostages and clashed with the militants, reportedly with the help of French military forces. The clashes continued until the next day. In the course of the siege, 17 people were killed, including 5 militants, five soldiers, and foreign civilians, including UN employees. Al Mourabitoune claimed responsibility and authorities believe the newly formed Katiba Macina may have been involved. Fatalities are split across two events.

actor2: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
notes: Rival factions within the security forces clashed around the state television and radio complex, fighting intense battles until the pro-coup troops were repulsed. A total of 12 mutineers were killed and 30 injured in the fighting over two days. Anti-coup forces repelled a major attack by rival troops, leaving at least three dead. Gunfire and clashes were reported throughout the city and smoke could be seen on Bujumburas skyline. A total of 12 mutineers were killed and 30 injured in the fighting over two days.

actor2: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
notes: Police and/or military forces stormed the Bumerec Private Hospital looking for coup leaders, leading to a gunbattle with pro-coup soldiers inside which left at least one injured and perhaps one dead. The police withdrew but later attacked and searched the hospital, firing live ammunition, causing significant material damage, and taking three pro-coup soldiers captive.

actor2: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)

actor2: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
notes: A group of soldiers 'mutinied' and Major General Godefroid Niyombare publicly declared a coup d'etat, but President Nkurunziza claimed the government still had control and that loyalists within the military 'fought off rival soldiers'. After the coup declaration, police withdrew from the streets and protesters celebrated freely. A total of 12 mutineers were killed and 30 injured in the fighting over two days.

actor2: Military Forces of Burundi (2005-) Niyombare Faction

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

notes: Around 400 residents of Kaga Bandoro armed with knives and other weapons attacked the MINUSCA base during protests to demand protection from armed Fulani who have recently attacked nearby villages. Gunfire was exchanged outside the base, while demonstrators threw stones and other objects at MINSUCA peacekeepers and attempted to set the camp on fire. Warning shots were fired by the peacekeepers. At least one protester was killed, and more than 12 people were wounded. Some reports have the number as high as 3.

Clashes between communities in Minkamman over a disputed ruling made by a traditional court. 27 injured and taken to the hospital.

Gunmen attacked a Malian military position near Burkina Faso and a firefight ensued, resulting in the death of three militants.

On 29 December 2014, 5 were injured in a brawl in Nimule (Eastern Equatoria state) between members of the Ayual sub-section of the Lith Twic East section and the Juet sub-section of the Athoc section of the Bor Dinka. The brawl broke out after several young Juet women were attacked by Ayual youths.

4 people were seriously injured in a clash over a land dispute between young people from the Gatumba and Rukaramu areas. Police arrived and fired into the air several times to disperse the two groups who were fighting with machetes.
Communal violence was reported in Panawac. Police have also deserted in the Panawac area.

At least 35 people were killed (estimates have been as high as 53) in communal violence between the Gony and Thuyiic clans in Rumbek East county in the areas of Pacong, Panawac and Malek. Police have deserted these areas fearing attacks by armed pastoralists. 156 others have been confirmed wounded, including 4 SPLA soldiers. Kok-Keer and Kok-Awac were also said to have been among the dead and wounded.

Around 21 December 2014 (as reported), at least 3 people were killed during fighting between the Pukun and Tuba sections of the Luo at an unspecified location(s) in Kangi payam in Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), with the clashes initiated by the Pukun in revenge for the killing of their Paramount Chief on 19 Dec. Unconfirmed reports say that SPLA deserters were participating in the clashes.

Around 22 September 2014, an unspecified security forces (provisionally coded as SPLA) clashed with armed youth from the Thiik subsection of the Aliap section of the Rek Dinka who had earlier attacked Pan-miir cattle camp in Kirik payam [event coded to Kirik, Tonj North county, Warrap state]. One of the armed youth was killed in the shootout, while 2 others were wounded, and six arrested.

source: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and armed Fulani have killed nine people and injured several others. Fulanis were reported to have left the area a week prior, as a large number of Anti-Balaka arrived in the town. After the clashes, they re-took control of the town, and looted a number of properties.

On 8 September 2014, clashes broke out between the Adeel and Thuch sections of the Luach-Jang Dinka clan at an unspecified location in Tonj East county (Warrap state), implied to be in the Makuac area [coded to Makwoich at GP2]. At least 40 people were killed (16 from the Adeel, and 24 from the Thuch) and 66 wounded in fighting which spilled over to 8 September (40 fatalities distributed across two events). The fighting may have been sparked by an elopement or an abduction of a girl.

Around 7 September 2014 (weekend of), clashes broke out between the Adeel and Thuch sections of the Luach-Jang Dinka clan at an unspecified location in Tonj East county (Warrap state), implied to be in the Makuac area [coded to Makwoich at GP2]. Military spokesperson yesterday in press briefing put Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) death toll to 64 soldiers killed following Monday fighting. For the past three days there has been continuous aggression of aerial bombardment by Khartoum in Warguet, Majak Woi and Kiirkou in Northern Bahr el Ghazal State.
South Sudan said Monday said 10 people, most of whom were innocent civilians, have lost their lives following an attack allegedly carried out by the armed forces of the neighboring Sudan.

South Sudan accused the government of Sudan of resuming attacks it said were largely targeting civilian populations. Aguer said the SAF attacks took place on Monday and Tuesday, and were 'largely targeting innocent civilian settlements' in Northern Bahr el Ghazal state. An SPLA position in Warguet was also targeted, according to Aguer.
Aguer claimed a 15 May attack took place north of Wedakona in Unity state. He said a SAF attack on the area was immediately rpulsed by the SPLA, back to White Nile state.
UPDF capture Caesar Achellam, along with his wife, daughter, and assistant, one of the top 5 commanders in the LRA after an ambush of LRA camp.

On 10 May 2012, a car belonging to the South Sudan Ministry of Roads and Bridges was traveling from Juba to Jonglei when its was attacked by suspected Murle ethnic militia members near Panwell village of Bangachorot. Two policemen were wounded and the driver was killed, according to Jonglei police.

On 9 May 2012, Murle cattle raiders clashed with SPLA at an unspecified location in Twic East county (Kongor, Jonglei state; event coded to admin2 HQ of Panyagor) following a raid which killed two people and wounded one other (one event coded). 32 head of stolen cattle were retrieved by the army.

On 24 December 2011, suspected rebels under the command of renegade general George Athor attacked the area of Atar town in Canal/Pigi county (Jonglei state) killing three SPLA and six civilians. Event presumed to have been an armed clash.

notes: Up to 8,000 members of the Lou Nuer militia raided villages in Pibor county to attack members of the Murle tribe, reportedly recovering dozens of abducted children and thousands of cattle stolen in August. No report of causalities, though there has been many since their fighting began in June 2011. SPLA and UNMISS allegedly sent reinforcements to Pibor to repel the attackers, however fighting continued. 30 reported killed.

South Sudanese rebel chief George Athor has been killed in a clash with soldiers of South Sudan. One other fighter killed. Many homes were destroyed due to clashes. Members of other southern rebel groups allege that Athor was killed in a visit to president Museveni of Uganda.
Police forces quickly arrest two individuals in connection with an attack on a mission.
Security forces shoot and kill 18 armed rebels. Many of the others fled across the border into Tanzania.

Sudanese forces cross the border into Upper Nile State and attacked a base controlled by the SPLA, 18 dead 73 wounded. The SPLA believes Sudanese forces are trying to capture the surrounding oil fields. Sudanese forces were eventually driven back across the border.

A faction of SSLM/A who had rejected the ceasefire deal signed by SSLM/A leader Gadet in August 2011 clashed with SPLA forces in Mayom. 60 rebels were killed when government forces repelled the attack. 15 civilians were also killed when they were shot by rebels as they ran for shelter. 18 others were wounded. Conflicting reports have the numbers of dead at 39, others 80, while the rebels claimed to have taken Mayom town and Tomor, capturing SPLA soldiers and seizing weapons in the process.

A large group of LRA attacked a police station, clinic, and several households in Deim Jallab, S. Sudan, on September 4th. They looted food, household goods, 3 AK-47s, and abducted 4 people. Last month, the LRA attacked this community 3 times.

Two people were killed and three others injured on Sunday, as police officers clashed with students at the Mutunga university campus in Burundi during a search operation, reliable sources have told APA.
A arms dealer is killed in the extreme north of the county while ferrying weapons to rebels in Libya. It is unclear as to the circumstance of his death.
The South Sudanese military touts it has made gains by expelling all northern forces from Kaka.
'1 INGO national staff killed and 8 INGO national staff wounded during clashes between suspected elements of a rebel militia group and Sudanese armed forces.'
A clash between Sudanese forces and the rebel group lead by Athor clash, killing 60 and injuring 43.

15 South Sudanese fighters were killed, 31 injured, in clashes with Shilluk rebels who crossed the border to Kaka from a rear base in South Kordofan on 19 and 20 August. 57 Shilluk rebels were also allegedly killed in the incident.

15 South Sudanese fighters are killed, 31 injured in clashes with border-crossing Sudanese forces, who attacked several towns, including an unnamed area on day two, and returned across the border the following day. 57 members of the raiding force were killed in the incident. Many believe this was an effort by the north to intimidate civilians expose the Souths new government as a failure.

After three days of cattle raids and clashes with authorities at total of 600 are reported dead, another 985 reported injured. Over 25,000 heads of cattle stolen, which are a fixture of the local economy.

15 South Sudanese fighters were killed, 31 injured, in clashes with Shilluk rebels who crossed the border to Kaka from a rear base in South Kordofan on 19 and 20 August. 57 Shilluk rebels were also allegedly killed in the incident.

Cattle raiders from Sudan continue clashes and raids on villages of Pieri District.

Cattle raiders of the Murle ethnic group crossed the border from Sudan, raided and looted five unincorporated locations in Jonglei state including the villages of Matot, Pulchuol, Guancot, Rumaker, Dorganwel, and Tongyang. This is believed to be revenge against the Lou Nuer tribe for earlier raids against them.

Police killed two gunmen in Burundis capital after a heavy exchange of fire, police said on Tuesday, the latest in a series of incidents that have raised fears of a new rebellion in the coffee producing nation.

Gunmen killed one soldier and seriously wounded five people in western Burundi, the latest attack in a spate of violent incidents that have raised fears of a new insurgency. In Wednesdays incident, armed men in the western district of Gihanga ambushed and killed a soldier and wounded five people, including two nuns and a priest, an official said. - Reuters

Initial reports attributed the killing to the SPLA, whilst subsequent reports suggested an officer within Gatluak Gai's rebel movement was responsible for the killing (which subsequent reporting used to determine the coding of actor2 as Gatluak Gai).

Three people were killed in the south of Burundi after a clash between police and gunmen in the latest in a series of violent incidents that have increased fears of a new insurgency in the central African nation. two armed men and a police officer were killed in a clash on Tuesday in Kizuka village in the southern district of Rumonge, Gerard Ndikumana, a district official, said on Wednesday.

At least nine people have been killed in western Burundi in the latest battles between the country's security forces and unidentified gunmen on 19 and 20 July. The most recent incident occurred when the gunmen ambushed a taxi in the north-west Cibitoke province, leading to the death of two soldiers, a police officer and six 'gangsters', according to Agence France-Presse (AFP).

actor1: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
notes: CPJP capture town from army, who had controlled it since Nov.15 (from UN). 12 soldiers killed, 1 CPJP, and at least 11 captured, including head of Presidential Guard and deputy. The CPJP initiated the attack. Government forces claimed to have regained the area after air and ground battles on the night of 25 to 26 October, however fighting continued in the following days and the rebels were said to have been entirely removed from the town by Chadian forces after air and ground fighting over 29-30 November. 71 persons are reported killed after the fighting in Birao, including 65 CPJP rebels (fatalities spread over several days of fighting).

Two people, including a policeman, were also killed in the eastern province of Cankuzo Tuesday night. Police sources there say gunmen in military fatigue targeted a bar. Before retreating, they looted the shops nearby.

Four people were killed Tuesday night in two separate incidents in Burundi. In one of the incidents, the police and the army organized a joint operation to dislodge a group of gunmen at Vugizo in the southern Makamba province. Military sources in Bujumbura say the army and police exchanged fire with gunmen at Vugizo in the south of Burundi. Security forces worked on a tip off that a group of gunmen was circulating in the area. Army spokesman Gaspard Baratuza says two gunmen were killed and two others captured. Two of the attackers had deserted from security forces.

Burundian soldiers clashed with armed gangs in the west of the country in two separate incidents that resulted in the death of a civilian, officials said Wednesday. Soldiers acting on a tip-off ambushed a group of armed men in the western Rugazi region late Tuesday, sparking an hour-long firefight that forced the gang to retreat to a nearby forest, said Gaspard Baratuza, the army spokesman. He said a civilian was killed by mistake when a soldiers who laid an ambush at night fired at people they thought were bandits.
